awd_abstract_narration:
CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Quickest Change Detection Techniques with Signal Processing Applications

Project abstract

The problem of detecting changes in stochastic systems, often referred to as sequential change detection or quickest change detection, arises in various branches of science and engineering. In all these applications, an anomaly in the environment changes in some way the distribution of the sequentially acquired observations. The goal is to detect the change and raise an alarm as soon as possible, so that any necessary action can be taken in time, while controlling the rate of false alarms below an acceptable level. While the quickest change detection problem has been actively studied since early 1950s, there are many open challenges in this field that are of theoretical as well as practical interest. 

This research addresses long-standing open problems in quickest change detection, as well as challenging problems that are motivated by modern applications, such as the following: 1) Optimum quickest change detection for Markov data; 2) Optimum quickest detection for transient changes; 3) (Asymptotically) optimum quickest change detection schemes for multistream data when changes are sparse; 4) Joint quickest change detection and isolation (localization of the change) in multistream data; 5) Controlled sensing for quickest change detection and isolation with composite post change hypothesis; 6) Data-driven quickest outlier detection and isolation. Furthermore, the investigators study the applications of their results in the following areas: 1) Line outage detection in power systems; 2) Epidemic detection; 3) Change detection in financial applications; 4) Surveillance using sensor networks; 5) Dynamic spectrum sensing; 6) Intrusion detection in power grids/networks; 6) Anomaly and fraud detection in big data.

por.por_cntn:
This research program focused on problems related to sequential detection of changes with a parallel effort to develop machine learning methodologies and tools that are appropriate for the problem of interest.

 

Regarding the theory of sequential detection of changes, novel results were developed in the following directions: 1) Optimum change detection in Hidden Markov processes; 2) Optimum change detection of transient changes; 3) Subspace sequential change detection with application to seismic data; 4) Multistream change detection with sampling control; 5) Multistream quickest detection with sparse signals; 6) Optimum detection of dynamic anomalies; 7) Multichannel sequential detection; 8) Sequential multiple testing with error control. Also, the following topics related to sequential methodologies were studied: A) Sequential parameter estimation; B) Optimal sequential solution of the Secretary problem with random queries; C) Machine learning methods for the estimation of likelihood ratios with application to sequential detection.

 

Most of these results were the outcome of collaboration between the PIs. More specifically Veeravalli and Moustakides collaborated in 2), 5) and 6), while all three PIs, Fellouris, Veeravalli and Moustakides collaborated in the problems depicted in 7) and 8).

 

Regarding educational activities we must mention a) Invited presentations to various engineering and statistics conferences as: IEEE International Conference on Acoustic, Speech and Signal Processing (ICASSP); IEEE international Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT, also plenary speaker); IEEE Global Conference on Signal and Information Processing; International Workshop on Applied Probability (IWAP); International Workshop on Sequential Methodologies (IWSM, also plenary speaker); Asilomar Conference on Signals, Systems, and Computers and Allerton Conference on Communication Control and Computing;  b) Invited presentations at universities and institutes: Huawei Technologies, Paris, France; Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania; Industrial and Systems Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology (twice); Institut de Mathématiques de Toulouse, Toulouse, France. c) In addition to the two new graduate courses developed at UIUC, PI Moustakides developed the undergraduate course "Processing methods with machine learning techniques" where classical detection and estimation theory is revisited from a purely data-driven and machine learning angle. Specifically, well-known optimality results are redeveloped in the absence of probability densities. The corresponding techniques are then applied to popular problems from Computer Vision using real data.

 

At Rutgers, this project supported two graduate students, two postdoctoral fellows and one visiting fellow. The graduate students were trained in sequential analysis and optimal stopping theory but also in machine learning focusing on the consistency analysis of training methods. The two postdoctoral fellows devoted their energy on hard-core sequential change detection problems with emphasis in continuous-time and continuous path processes. Finally, the visiting fellow contributed to the application of machine learning estimation methods in popular problems from to Computer Vision.
